answers.answer: Based on your description, I would have thought it may be a problem with your retina, so that is interesting that the retina specialist was unable to find anything wrong.  Have you had an automated visual field test?  The pattern of any detectable visual field loss would be useful to determine if the blind spot is from glaucoma, retinal detachment, or even a lesion behind the eye.  If all else fails, I would seek a second opinion or perhaps a neuroophthalmologist if one is available in your area.

question: In my right eye..I have a blind spot...for example covers one of the letters in each word that I am typing.  Outside...it will cover one of the numbers on a speed limit sign.  It is annoying.  One other weird symptom...when looking at say a telephone pole. I see it in sections not one continuous vertical item. Sometimes it appears wavy...sometimes segmented.I have been to a retina specialist and to ophthalmologists.  They regard it as nothing.  But they dont have to live with it.  What causes this.   Yes I have had auras for years, but this is different. I have had detached retinas in both eyes, but this looks nothing like that either.  My blood pressure is fine if and a bit on the low side. No to diabetes.
title: permanent blind spot
